image.alt_text: Photo by ᴅᴀɴᴛᴇ ʙɪꜱꜱ-ɢʀᴀʏꜱᴏɴ in Taos, New Mexico. May be an image of outdoors.
image.caption:
Un-forgotten
 The missing women, The Lost Daughters, the Unforgotten.
The cries are heard Throughout the Valley. She runs at night,
Hunted under the Moon, She flees.
Her body goes numb,
Mind distant,
She keeps her fire close to her heart.
Grandmothers weep,
Families Cry,
The missing women are not forgotten.
The snow breaks under her weight, Barefoot and cold...Bleeding,
She looks to the horizon, not looking back.
She runs, And flees, And Fights! Memories of hope,
Not forgotten...
We the living hunt for the lost.
Taken from us,
Taken from her child, Taken from her dreams...
Her shell dress moves

 To the wind,
"Your spirit is with us!"
The Tribe does not sleep Until she
Comes Home

“Resilience: Honoring Those Lost, Those Murdered, and Those Who Still Search” Poetry and Discussion with Osage Artist Dante Biss-Grayson 

@iaismuseum 
@fivepointsartsct 
@skyeaglecollection 

Stat @newsweek 

“Over the Last Decade, 466 Indigenous Women we’re reported Missing in Wyoming, the same state where Gabby Petito was last seen.” (Newsweek)

The installation explores the root causes of the MMIW epidemic. Through spreading awareness the artist promotes actionable change. According to the Urban Health Institute, 5,712 cases of MMIW were reported in 2016, of these, only 116 were logged into the Department of Justice Database. (@urbanindianhealthinstitute )

Dante Biss-Grayson, in this ongoing installation honors those lost, those missing, and those murdered. The work is a live creation which will include, open discussions, poetry creation, art creation, new media, and virtual activism via social media platforms. By creating art, and externalizing the emotions felt, the artist intends to bring greater awareness to this issue, and inspire action.

Space is limited for the in-person event; pre-registration is recommended.Questions? Please call (860) 868-0518 or email events@iaismuseum.org. This is a FREE event, but donations are appreciated.

Donations will go towards a scholarship fund for emerging Native artists

image.alt_text: Photo by Our Wisconsin Revolution 📢✊🏼 on November 02, 2021. May be an image of road, snow and text that says 'Enbridge's Line 3 Pipeline: Mixing Oil and Sexual Violence ByJhanDahanyakaOnNov1,2021 On Nov 1, 2021 By Jihan Dahanayaka CONSTRUCTION PIPELINE AHEAD'.
image.caption:
CONTENT ADVISORY: Sexual Assault

“The link between mining and oil extraction industries with sexual violence and trafficking in the United States is neither a recent nor unique phenomenon in oil boom towns worldwide. In the simplest terms, sudden increases of economic activity (i.e., construction) into underdeveloped areas necessarily create an influx of workers, which, from a State Department report, “create[s] a demand for commercial sex.” Much of this illicit sexual activity, violence, and trafficking occur in areas near or around “man camps,” the temporary housing built for the construction workers. Consequently, the construction of man camps in primarily poor, remote, and Indigenous communities goes hand-in-hand with increases in violence, sexual assault, sexually transmitted diseases, prostitution, and illicit drugs. 

While these issues impact boom-town Indigenous communities as a whole, it is the Native missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls (MMIWG) that are the greatest victims. At the time of writing, Indigenous women are being murdered at a rate of over ten times the U.S. national average. Over 80 percent of Indigenous people have experienced violence in their lifetime; they are 2.5 times more likely to experience violent crime and twice as likely than other races to experience rape or sexual assault.”

#StopLine3 #Enbridge #Line3 #MMIWG #Wisconsin #Minnesota #Michigan #Indigenous

image.alt_text: Photo by War Party Movement in Albuquerque, New Mexico with @justine_jorelle12. May be an image of 1 person, standing, outdoors and brick wall.
image.caption:
AN OVERVIEW OF MMIW IN URBAN AMERICA

71% of American Indians/ Alaska Natives live in urban areas. Urban Indians are tribal people currently living off federally- defined tribal lands in urban areas.

Despite this ongoing crisis, there is a lack of data and an inaccurate understanding of MMIW, creating a false perception that the issue does not affect off-reservation/ village American Indian and Alaska Native communities. Data collected through FOIA requests by The Urban Indian Heath Institute in 71 cities for 2020. 

506 MMIW cases where identified in 71 cities. 
128 Missing Indigenous women cases
280 Murdered Indigenous women cases
98 Unknown status
29 Years old is the median age of victims 

The 506 cases identified were dispersed over a wide geographic area. Regionally, the Southwest (157), Northern Plains (101), Pacific Northwest (84), Alaska (52), and California (40) were the areas with the highest number of cases. The cities that figure most prominently in the data are Seattle (45), Albuquerque (37), Anchorage (31), Tucson (31), and Billings (29).

Seventy-one city police agencies and one state police agency were surveyed. Forty agencies (56%) provided some level of data. Thirty-three of the 40 (and 46% of all surveyed) actually searched their records, though not all provided comprehensive data. Ten out of the 40 agencies provided data but with a “caveat”, meaning they only confirmed cases that had already logged, provided what they could recall from memory, or gave partial data. Fourteen of the 72 agencies surveyed (20%) did not provide data, and 18 (25%) are still pending. Those combined with the 10 “caveat” cases comprised 59% of all the agencies surveyed. In sum, nearly two-thirds
of all agencies surveyed either did not provide data or provided partial data with significant compromises.

The Missing Murdered Indigenous Women crisis is not just a problem facing us on Reservations and Indian Communities, this is in your city and in your town! 

#warpartymovement

image.alt_text: Photo by Otto Rollins & GiGi L’il Bits in Turkey Day with @sweetpiggybaker, @dogsofcharmcity, and @theplussizepooch.
image.caption:
Happy Thanksgiving everypawdy! 🦃 Our momma calls this a “conflicted” holiday. We ❤️ 🦃 & 🎃 🥧 & having a day to be thankful for those we ❤️ & all we have … but Thanksgiving is not ALL ☮️, ❤️ & pass the gravy.
⠀
We can’t furget that the hoomans who colonized 🇺🇸 stole the land from Native Americans who lived here 1st. Even before the 1st Thanksgiving feast between the Plymouth settlers & the Wampanoag, & after it too, lots of🩸was shed & lives were lost 😞
⠀
So for New England’s tribes, today is a National Day of Mourning to recognize the genocide of millions of Native Americans, the theft of their land & the centuries of racism & mistreatment indigenous hoomans have faced around the 🌎
⠀
It’s your choice how you celebrate today (we won’t judge because we have 🦃 & 🥧 too), but you can still help raise awareness. Pawlease remember: there’s  history & then there’s what most of our hoomans were taught (or ARE #being taught) in school.  Let’s get history right!
⠀
So as you give 🙏🏻 for all you are grateful for today (because we know there’s a LOT for all of us to be thankful for), maybe pawse for a moment to honor indigenous hoomans by committing to educate yourself & do better … maybe even ask why missing & murdered indigenous women & girls seem to go unnoticed while some other missing young girls make national news … just barkin’ 😠
⠀
We think that the only way to make our future better for everypawdy is to acknowledge our history & treat all hoomans as equal. That shouldn’t be so hard, right?
⠀
⠀
🦃 Team Leftovers & Pies Before Guys Tees: @theplussizepooch
⠀
🥧 Pumpkin Pie: @sweetpiggybaker 🙏🏻 to @dogsofcharmcity
⠀
⠀

We will not stop until there is justice.'.
image.caption:
Repost from @seedingsovereignty using @RepostRegramApp - National Human Trafficking Awareness Day 01/11⁠
⁠
As of 2016, there were only 5,712 reports of missing AI/AN women and girls—the US Department of Justice’s federal missing persons database only logged 116 of those reports. Murder is the third leading cause of death for AI/AN women and girls—the numbers for missing and murdered Indigenous persons is unimaginable at this rate. ⁠
⁠
We rely on our own communities to help fight for justice. Today, in particular, we would like to highlight some resources for you in addition to our own MMIP initiative. ⁠
⁠
Bring our relatives home. ⁠
⁠

image.alt_text: Photo by shawneechief on February 07, 2022. May be an image of horse and text that says '1 SEEA TIME OF SEVEN GENERATIONS WHEN ALL THE COLORS OF MANKIND WILL GATHER UNDER THE SACRED TREE OF LIFE AND THE WHOLE EARTH WILL BECOME ONE CIRCLE AGAIN CRAZY HORSE FACEBOOK DIE JRDIANER'.
image.caption:
The Hunkpapa Lakota man Crazy Horse had a final vision in which 'He saw his people being driven into spiritual darkness and poverty while the white people prospered in a material way all around them. But even in the darkest times, he saw that the eyes of a few of his people kept the light of dawn and the wisdom of the earth, which they passed on to some of their grandchildren. He saw the coming of automobiles and airplanes, and twice he saw the great darkness and heard the screams and explosions when millions of people died in two great world wars. 'But he saw, after the second great war passed, a time come when his people began to awaken, not all at once, but a few here and there, and then more and more, and he saw that they were dancing in a beautiful light of the Spirit World under the Sacred Tree even while still on Earth. Then he was amazed to see that dancing under the tree were representatives of all races who had become brothers and sisters, and he realized that the world would be made new again and in peace and harmony not just by his people, but by members of all races of mankind.' Kiteyihtakosiw ekwa kihcheyihtakwan (Honor and respect) to Crazy Horse.🐎💕🐎

image.alt_text: Photo by Women Of The White Buffalo on January 21, 2022. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.
image.caption:
❗ In light of Human Trafficking Awareness Month, which is in January of every year, we share two important organisations that are in the fight against human trafficking in the US. 

❗ Human trafficking is a global issue but in the US alone, the average age of a child sex trafficking victim is 15; 98% of victims in active criminal sex trafficking cases in 2020 were female and 83% of purchases of illicit sex happened online. (from Deliver Fund Organization website)

Vandee Crane Khalsa-SwiftBird, one of the women featured in Women Of The White Buffalo, is a descendant of the WahZahZhi and Eastern Band Cherokee Nations and is affiliated with the Oglala Lakota tribe through marriage. Vandee is a survivor of drug abuse and teen sex-trafficking. She has dedicated her life’s work to grassroots efforts on behalf of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls (#MMIWG).

💜 Vandee is also the founder of Rise In Love Foundation, an organization that works to support individuals, families, and communities in healing ancestral trauma, providing the support that victims need to become victors over any circumstance. 
 
🔦 DeliverFund is a non profit intelligence organization working to end human trafficking in America, using cutting-edge technology. 

🌍 Both organisations are in line with, and try to tackle, numbers 5 and 16 of the 17 United Nations Sustainable Goal; Gender equality & Peace, justice and strong institutions.

☝ Please head to the link in our bio to find out more about these organizations and donate to this extremely important cause.

@riseinlovefoundation
@deliverfund

📸  @vandeecrane and TatankaSka Win SwiftBird, who are both featured in the the documentary film Women Of The White Buffalo. Shot by @deborahandersoncreative

image.alt_text: Photo by NCAI on November 26, 2021. May be an image of child, flower and text.
image.caption:
One cannot truly understand Native America without understanding the historical, political, and cultural role Native women hold within Tribal Nations. For generations, our grandmothers, mothers, sisters, and daughters have maintained our cultures, protected our families, and supported our governments.⠀
⠀
Despite progress made in recent decades, several inequalities persist. Through a continued push for #VAWA reauthorization and efforts to increase the awareness and protection of #MMIWG, ensuring the safety of Native women remains a critical focus of NCAI’s work.⠀
⠀
#NativeAmericanHeritageMonth #NativeAmericanHeritageDay #NAHM2021

May be an image of text that says 'IN HONOUR OF MMIWG Make your own Red Dress Pin WHEN MONDAY JANUARY 31, 2022 11:00 AM 12:00 PM EST WHAT WORKSHOP CRAFT MATERIALS TO BE PROVIDED REGISTER VIA EVENTBRITE LINK IN DESCRIPTION GUEST SPEAKER STEVI RILEY ATLOHSA ILY FAMILY HEALING Y SERVICES'.
image.caption:
Virtual beading class for community members with bead craftswoman, Stevi Riley. In this session, she will be teaching participants how to bead the red dress pin. The red dress pin is a wonderful addition to any wardrobe or work lanyard to actively honour, remember, and talk about issues concerning Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls.

All beading materials will be provided in advance (London area only). Limited spots available. To register, please visit mmiwg-workshop.eventbrite.ca

Guest speaker bio:
Stevi Riley is an Ojibwe bead craftswoman and has shared her gifts in Indigenous community wellness. Stevi has a passion for seeing education be more easily accessible to Indigenous young people.

image.alt_text: Photo by Brandi Morin on December 22, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, sky and grass.
image.caption:
Well, I’m not done yet as more stories of mine are being published before 2022, but man it’s been a wild and breathtaking ride of a year!! 
From Wet’suewet’en territories last February to work on major #MMIWG industry series w @photobracken to dealing with the ongoing pandemic; working with @journalistsforhumanrights & mentoring up & coming Indigenous media makers; also mentoring with @canadianassociationjournalists with passionate young journalists; to Fairy Creek blockades covering land defenders protecting the old growth forests in June for @ricochet_en & stopping to honour the 215 children’s graves found at Kamloops Indian Residential School & grappling with that trauma; to Carlisle, Pennsylvania & Lakota lands in July with @natgeo & @dzalcman documenting the historic repatriation of Lakota children who died at Indian boarding school; to Northern Cali in August for @natgeo to do their first ever feature on MMIWG; did countless TV, podcast, doc interviews & university presentations involving my work from around the world; to Cowessness Reserve in September to meet w residential school survivors; back to Fairy Creek in October met with violence & arrests of land defenders via police w @raulgallegoabellan for @aljazeeraenglish then to Tuktoyuktuk in the Arctic in early November to do a film on #climatechange then back to Wet’suewet’en territories in November to cover a revolution of Indigenous and allied land defenders against CGL LNG pipeline & police; co-hosting episodes of @auntie.up amazing all-star Iskwew production; keynote @ywca_edmonton Rose Campaign; to speaking at the @unfpa w Center for Women’s Global Leadership; to writing bi-monthly badass op ed’s w @thetorontostar AND writing my book, first ever, memoir OUR VOICE OF FIRE with my stunning editor Joanna Henry for @houseofanansi then to pitching major documentary to Hollywood with the help of incredible friend, mover & shaker and ally @markruffalo 
I’ve had sleepless nights, cried hard, laughed tons, filled with love & knocked down but inspired by this work I’m so friggen honoured & blessed to do!! I love you all- just getting started. Kisakihitin ❤️❤️❤️ 

📸 Taken @ Rosebud Sioux Nation by @dzalcman

image.alt_text: Photo by Tribal_sioux on December 09, 2021. May be an image of text.
image.caption:
We who walk the Red Road have been chosen to be the sacred torchbearers, giving of our light to illuminate the darkness and to bring a lasting love, peace and harmony to Mother Earth. We will never waver but keep our torch burning until we all unite together in one sacred circle, all people from different nations with one vision, one struggle, and one prayer to start living in a sacred way. We will not be separated by beliefs, language, gender or politics but we will be united in heart and spirit. We will see through the false illusions of what keeps us separated and we will all realise that we have the same hopes and dreams. It will be the love for Mother Earth and the Great Spirit that will hold us in this divine bond and to keep our torch burning in our hearts. We all have heard the sacred calling and now we must all answer to it. 🌎🔥💧

image.caption:
MMIWGT2S 🤍 with Valentine’s Day approaching, I will be making red dress earrings to honour the Indigenous women, girls, trans and two-spirit relatives who have been taken through racialized /gendered violence. 

Over the next few weeks I will be adding red dress earrings to my sales with the intention of raising funds for the Native Women’s Shelter of Montreal. 
 
To learn more check out the “national inquiry into MMIWGT2S” website mmiwg-ffada.ca

image.alt_text: Photo by Tribal_sioux on January 04, 2022. May be a black-and-white image of one or more people.
image.caption:
Dahteste was a Choconen Apache woman warrior, and being married and having children didn’t stop her to participate in many raiding parties together with her first husband Ahnandia. Later in her life, she joined the legendary Geronimo, together with another famous woman warrior called Lozen. Besides being a brave and skilled as a warrior, she was also fluent in English and served as a messenger and translator for the Apache. Dahteste became a mediator between the U.S. Cavalry (sometimes serving as their scout) and Geronimo. She played an important role in his final surrender in 1886. Where do you think she learned to speak English, fluently?

image.caption:
Very excited to finally announce my latest #Musuem #soloexhibition opening at the @utahmuseumoffinearts . Special thanks and gratitude to @keoqui for this amazing opportunity. 
_________________________________

David Rios Ferreira: Transcending Time and Space
Featuring work and writing by artist Denae Shanidiin

MARCH 19, 2022 TO DECEMBER 4, 2022
_________________________________

Merging #sciencefiction with cultural and #spiritual traditions, Transcending Time and Space asks you to contemplate those you might’ve lost, those you miss across distances, and even those you have yet to meet. 

The #artworks in this ACME Lab #exhibition exist as imagined #gateways , objects through which we may connect with those we cannot reach on this plane. 

Ferreira was moved to create the work in this exhibition around the ever-growing tragedy of missing and murdered #Indigenous people #mmiwg —something he explores in collaboration with @denaeshanidiin  @restoringancestralwinds , a Tribal coalition responding to the violence perpetrated on Indigenous communities within the Great Basin and strengthening the traditional values of Indigenous relations.
______________________________

image.alt_text: Photo by arapahoindigenous on February 11, 2022.
image.caption:
Pg-1 Left-photo of Cree First Nations Chief Paskwa circa-1880's, Right- is a two-panel graphite and ledger depiction of the Treaty 4 negotiations between the First Nations people of what is now southern Saskatchewan, and parts of Manitoba and Alberta, and the Crown, represented by then-Lt.-Gov. Alexander Morris. The pictograph was drafted by Chief Paskwa in 1883, nine years after the signing of the treaty in 1874. It is the only document depicting Treaty 4 negotiations from an Indigenous perspective, said Evelyn Siegfried, curator of Indigenous studies at the Royal Saskatchewan Museum, 'It's priceless. It's very significant. It basically is a social comment on what the treaty was about, items that were promised by Lt.-Gov. Morris on behalf of the British crown, and then what had been received by Treaty 4 peoples following the signing of the treaty,' Siegfried said. The top depicts the interpretation of the negotiations from the perspective of the Pasqua First Nation. The bottom shows the supplies promised in the treaty, such as agriculture tools and the outfits promised to the chief and headmen. Pg.2- full photo of Chief Paskwa pictograph and history behind re-acquisition.

image.alt_text: Photo by Canadian True Crime in 白馬市. May be an image of one or more people and text.
image.caption:
15 year old Maranda Shelly Peter was reported missing from Whitehorse, Yukon on March 5, 1996. 

This is the first mention of her disappearance in the local print media - from page 2 of the March 22, 1996 edition of the Whitehorse STAR. By this point it had been almost three weeks after she went missing. 

Maranda had a history of running away but she had never been gone longer than a week.

 This is the only photo that is publicly available of her. Her name was misspelled "Miranda" in the initial media reporting. 

Listen to Canadian True Crime, Episode 97: The Murder of Maranda Shelly Peter on Apple Podcasts, your favourite podcast app, or stream at canadiantruecrime.ca/episodes.
Image source: Whitehorse Daily Star

image.alt_text: Photo by Ma Mawi Wi Chi Itata Centre in Treaty No. 1. May be an image of outdoors.
image.full_name: Ma Mawi Wi Chi Itata Centre
image.caption:
Looking for a fun, free, and educational outing this weekend? We recommend paying a visit to Rainbow Butterfly (the Red Dress Warming Hut) at the Forks!

Rainbow Butterfly is a community initiative to honour MMIWG2S+ on the Red River Mutual Trail. She aims to bring awareness to MMIWG2S+ and educate the public on the work currently happening in our community to address this national crisis. She also reminds us that our Indigenous women are water carriers, and she wears a QR code with a direct link to the 231 Calls for Justice to remind us of the work yet to be done. 

Learn more about Rainbow Butterly on her Facebook page here: https://www.facebook.com/collectiveofvoices/

Read the 231 Calls for Justice:
https://tinyurl.com/y33xxh34

image.alt_text: Photo by Maximiliano Storni on December 28, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of one or more people.
image.caption:
📌 Tanünuwün (Tanun o Manuela Casimiro) Mujer del pueblo Gününa Künna hija de Kuyáichim hermana de cacique Chagallo y esposa del lonko (cacique) Miguel Ñancuche

📸 Lehmann Nitsche
Ca.1903

Táünǘnuün  estaba  relacionada por distintos  vínculos  familiares con personas hablantes de  mapuzungun,  günün  a  iajüch,  aonek’o  y  probablemente teushen. Su imagen aparece  en  cuatro fotografías del  archivo del antropólogo Alemán Lehmann-Nitsche que luego fueron publicadas por Vignati (1942). En sus reversos  aparecen  los  nombres “Táünǘnuün” y “Tánun”  y la adscripción  identitaria de “Puelche”. En el  manuscrito del vocabulario se la presenta  como  hija de Kuyáichim, a quien se describe tehuelche,  pero cuyo  nombre personal  presenta el sufijo  femenino – chüm,  propio  de  la  lengua  de  los  günün  a  küne –  y Casimiro,  sindicado aquí como integrante de esta última  etnia, quien era a su vez primo de Kankel,  cacique tehuelche en la zona de Río Mayo, Chubut, Argentina.

📚Fuente:

"Ahúnik’ənk’. Un vocabulario de la lengua tehuelche documentado por Roberto Lehmann-Nitsche"

image.alt_text: Native woman dancing in traditional wear and a ribbon skirt
image.caption:
It’s that time of year again…full stop ✋🏾if you are thinking of dressing up as someone Indigenous for Halloween. Here are 3 reasons on why you shouldn’t. 🙅🏿‍♀️
1️⃣ Dressing up as someone Native feeds into the myth that we are no longer in existence. We are still very much here! 
2️⃣ “Native” oriented costumes are hyper-sexualized, and have a direct link to #MMIWG
3️⃣ It perpetuates the Native stereotypes in movies. Being Indigenous can have many meanings and looks, and it’s not what is found in Western movies! 

We want you to have fun on Halloween, but leave our culture out of it. #OurCultureIsNotYourCostume #HalloweenDonts #CultureIsNotACostume #NativeWYSE

image.alt_text: Photo by t on December 26, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, horse and outdoors.
image.caption:
On December 26, 1862, after the US-Dakota War of 1862, 38 Dakota men were publicly hanged in Mankato, MN. This was the largest mass execution in American history and was ordered by President Abraham Lincoln. In 1865, two more members of the Dakota tribe were hanged. 

Since 2005, the Dakota 38+2 Memorial Ride has commemorated this tragedy with a 330-mile and 17-day-long journey from Lower Brule, South Dakota to Mankato, Minnesota. 

If you want to learn more about this important (yet sadly overlooked) piece of history, I would recommend reading 38 Nooses by Scott W. Berg.

On December 26, 1862, after the US-Dakota War of 1862, 38 Dakota men were publicly hanged in Mankato, MN. This was the largest mass execution in American history and was ordered by President Abraham Lincoln. In 1865, two more members of the Dakota tribe were hanged. 

Since 2005, the Dakota 38+2 Memorial Ride has commemorated this tragedy with a 330-mile and 17-day-long journey from Lower Brule, South Dakota to Mankato, Minnesota. 

If you want to learn more about this important (yet sadly overlooked) piece of history, I would recommend reading 38 Nooses by Scott W. Berg.

image.alt_text: Photo by powhatannative on January 05, 2022. May be a closeup of one or more people.
image.caption:
Picture of Native Cahuilla Woman. The Cahuilla people also known as ʔívil̃uqaletem/Ivilyuqaletem are native people of the inland areas of Southern California. Their traditional home was to the north by the San Bernardino Mountains, to the south by Borrego Springs and the Chocolate Mountains, to the east by the Colorado Desert, and to the west by the San Jacinto Plain and the eastern slopes of the Palomar Mountains. The Cahuilla people lived from the land by using native plants. A notable tree whose fruits they harvested is the California fan palm. The Cahuilla also used palm leaves for basketry of many shapes, sizes and purposes; sandals, and roofing thatch for dwellings.
-

image.alt_text: Photo by Tribal_sioux on February 09, 2022. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'RESERVATION BOUNDRY The Brotherton Indian Reservation founded in 1758 began here and originally contained 3284 acres. The Indians moved to New York and the land was sold in 1802 at auction.'.
image.caption:
💔In 1758, European colonists opened the first Indian Reservation in New Jersey, called The Brotherton Reservation. Here was relocated the LENAPE people ... All Indian Reservations had a goal that is to bring Native American under U.S. government control and minimize conflicts between Native and the settlers. In this way the white settlers had the total freedom to steal the Native lands. The Reservations had the goal to encourage Native to take the way of living of the white man. Many Native were forced to move into the Reservations with catastrophic results for so many people. For example, the Santee were led into a land where the soil was arid, food was very difficult to find and the water was undrinkable.

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Fallon Farinacci on February 10, 2022 tagging @uglyshirt, @wsendzik, @k.dox, @shyann_jenkins, @downtownstcatharines, @meemmemaryellen, @rin_tin_tin98, @lori_littleton1, @cityofstcatharines, and @indigenous_niagara. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, monument and outdoors.
image.caption:
Presence through the marking of absence

This past Monday, February 7th, I had the honour of hanging a Red Dress at City of St.Catharines City Hall with community members I call friends & family @k.dox ,@meemmemaryellen , @indigenous_niagara, @shyann_jenkins, @rin_tin_tin98 , my husband Lucas and Vedder, @wsendzik, Leanne Kurek, @lori_littleton1 and @uglyshirt . 

We stood together to honour Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, 2SLGBTQQIA+ people.

The dress will hang in front of City Hall for the week leading up to February 14th, a day known National as a day to bring awareness to MMIWG2SLGBTQQIA+ people.

Jamie Black, a Métis Artist from Manitoba, started the REDress Project in 2011 as an art installation. The REDress project has since been replicated across Turtle Island from coast to coast. The empty red dresses signify the losses of Indigenous women, girls, & 2SLGTBQQIA+ people. Through the installation, Jamie aimed to bring attention to the gendered and racialized nature of violent crimes against Indigenous women, girls, 2SLGBTQQIA+ people and evoke a presence through the marking of absence.

I'm calling on you to hang a Red Dress in your front window or tree in your front yard. Together we can continue to bring awareness to MMIWG2SLGBTQQIA+ people.

I want to acknowledge that Mayor @wsendzik reached out to me to discuss having a Red Dress hang at City Hall. I'm glad we have a leader in our City who cares to have these conversations and is working towards making the changes we so desperately need to see for Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people. Many leaders in this Region could learn from Walter's Leadership.

Join me in honouring missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, 2SLGBTQQIA+ people, and hang a red dress in a window or a tree. 

#reddressproject #reddress #jamieblack #mmiwg2slgbtqqia+ #mmiwg #mmiw #redressproject

happy monday y’all! currently working on exciting things for our one year anniversary! I can’t believe that today is officially 1 month until we have been doing this podcast thing for an entire YEAR. It’s crazy to think of all the people we have met and connected with (you), the things we’ve learned, the support you’ve given us. It feels like we’re just getting started on our podcast journey and we have you to thank for that! 

If there’s a case you want us to cover or you want updates on drop them in the comments below so I can add to our 2022 plan 📝 as always love you all #podcastbyproxy #canadiantruecrime

image.alt_text: Photo by Betty Nippi-Albright in Saskatchewan, Canada. May be an image of outdoors and text.
image.caption:
The number of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two Spirit individuals across Canada is heartbreaking. 💔

The number is disproportionately high here in Saskatchewan.

Yet there was no acknowledgment of #MMIWG2S in the Sask. Party government’s recent Throne Speech.

The government committed $400,000 this fiscal year. If that was divided between the 6,928 eligible agencies - it would work out to $57.74 each.

How are #MMIWG going to be protected when all organizations apply for and receive this funding?

How is $57.74 going to protect anyone?

The message being sent by the Sask. Party here is - Indigenous women and girls don’t matter to their government.

The lack of acknowledgment and resources for #MMIWG2ST reinforces the narrative that Indigenous women are not important enough to be protected in this province.

👉🏼 Indigenous women are dying.
👉🏼 Indigenous girls are dying.
👉🏼 Two Spirit people are dying.

It is time to make our lives a priority.

Join me in demanding better. ✊🏼
#skpoli

image.alt_text: Photo by @pipikwanpehtakwan on November 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#EveryChildMattare EVERY CHILD MATTERS MT-711 AT'.
image.caption:
In June and September 2021, we were grateful to help Fort McKay Group of Companies with the unveiling of their ‘Red’ and ‘Orange’ trucks to raise awareness among their employees. 
 
The orange truck signifies the support of truth and reconciliation, and honours children who were forced to attend residential schools and those who never made it home. 
 
The red truck represents the missing and murdered indigenous women and girls (MMIWG) and 2SLGBTQQIA people. 
 
#FMGOC #MMIWG #2SLGBTQQIA

image.caption:
The #usmilitary has always gaslit its population into calling its expendable hitmen heroes and giving them medals of honor for land/ resource grabs and mass-murder 🧚🏽

*
Regram @thehumanityarchive
•
Today is the anniversary of the massacre at #WoundedKnee in 1890. 

Some say 150 others say up to 300 were killed (you know the math is always sketchy when the killers do the counting). I encourage you to research the whole story today.  But here are some words from someone who lived it, describing the killing of unarmed women and children.

This is the American history many  want to disremember. Congress should revoke those Medals of Honor awarded for the killings of Lakota Sioux people. Actually Congress should revoke all military medals.

image.alt_text: Photo by Maximiliano Storni on December 30, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and people standing.
image.caption:
📌 TRUQUEL SAYHUEQUE (hijo de Valentín Sayhueque, principal cacique Manzanero).

1 y 2. 📸 Joven Truquel, Cuarteles del Tigre, Buenos Aires, Arg.
ca.1885

3. 📸 Cacique Truquel Sayhueque, único sobreviviente de la tribu Manzanera, situada en Neuquén.
ca.1935

Estas 2 primeras fotos fueron tomadas en contexto de privacion ilegitima de la libertad de las familias de los caciques Sayhueque, Inacayal y Foyel (ultimos longkos de la patagonia) cautivos en los Cuarteles Militares de Tigre; uno de los tantos campos de concentración y exterminio. Fueron tomadas antes de que algunos de ellos fueran trasladados al Museo de La Plata como objetos de "estudio".
.

Los sobrevivientes de la llamada “Conquista del Desierto”, fueron arriados 1.400 kilómetros, desde los confines cordilleranos hasta Buenos Aires. Al llegar, hombres mujeres y niños fueron obligados a desfilar encadenados por las calles en un siniestro y vergonzoso “desfile de la victoria”.
.

Desde el puerto, los vencidos, fueron trasladados al campo de concentración en la isla Martín García y “depositados” en el Hotel de Inmigrantes, donde la clase dirigente de la época se dispuso a repartirse el botín, según lo cuenta el diario "El Nacional" que titulaba: “Entrega de indios”: "Los miércoles y los viernes se efectuará la entrega de indios y chinas a las familias de esta ciudad, por medio de la Sociedad de Beneficencia”.
.

Entre 1876 y 1903, el Estado Argentino regaló o vendió a un precio ridículo 41.787.023 hectáreas a 1.843 personas vinculadas estrechamente por lazos económicos o familiares a los diferentes gobiernos. En el actual Patio Bullrich de Buenos Aires funcionaba desde 1867 la casa de remates "Adolfo Bullrich y Cía", en la que se subastó gran parte del infausto botín de guerra.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Amanda Kennedy, Kuwahs^nahawi on January 31, 2022. May be an image of text that says 'Oh Canada our home and... No matter how many of our Women and girls are missing and murdered. MMIWG No matter how many our communities still don't have clean drinking water. No matter how much some of us and our ancestors have paid or pay the price for living. No matter how many of our children's bodies we dig up from Indian Residential Schools (7,500+) We will never have the support of this country as much as truckers that want mandates removed. You are all privileged to be here and it's due to the Genocide of the Indigenous People.'.
image.caption:
Our truth is… 

No matter how many of our women and girls are missing and murdered. 

No matter how many of our communities don’t have clean drinking water.

No matter how much some of us and our ancestors paid or pay the price for living. 

No matter how many of our children’s bodies we dig up from Indian Residential Schools (7,500+)…

We will never have the support of this country as much as truckers that want mandates removed. 

You are all privileged to be here and it’s due to the genocide of the Indigenous People.

Self-care is so important.  Your mental health is so important. Everyone, please take care of yourselves. You are needed. We are needed.

Yaw^ko, thank you, to those who are taking the time to reflect, listen, and learn.  Yaw^ko to you all for stepping out of your comfort zones, standing up and standing with us in unity and with love and respect.  This is our history, our truth and we need to change it for our future generations to come! 

We see you, we hear you and we appreciate you all! It’s time for us to all learn, heal and grow together.

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Gidimt’en Checkpoint on December 19, 2021 tagging @laylastaats. May be an image of snow.
image.caption:
BREAKING - Gidimt'en Clan Evicts CGL from Drill Site; Re-Occupies Coyote Camp

Early Sunday, Gidimt'en land defenders evicted Coastal Gaslink workers and re-established control of Coyote Camp, the site where Coastal Gaslink plans to drill beneath Wet'suwet'en headwaters.

This courageous action took place one month after a wave of militarized raids on Gidimt'en land, where police with assault weapons, dogs, and sniper rifles arrested 30 people, including land defenders, journalists, and legal observers.

Wet'suwet'en people have never surrendered this land, and we never will. Our lands are not for sale, and the safety of our waters is non-negotiable.

In early 2020, Hereditary Chiefs from all five clans of our nation stood together and issued an eviction to CGL. That eviction remains in force today.

We are calling for supporters to join us on the ground, or take action where you stand.

#AllOutForWedzinKwa

image.alt_text: Photo by indigenousgive on November 24, 2021.
image.caption:
Greatness is not about the fame you have achieved, nor is it being the best at what you do, it will never be the personal success that has been bestowed upon you, nor is it that you have gained more material items than others. For true greatness is that you have inspired others to be the best they can be, that you have left your light within others after you have been long gone. When others want to emulate your actions or words in a good way and are inspired by your energy, than you have fulfilled what truly was asked of you by the Great Mystery. For truly the talents and gifts we have humbly received were never meant for just our own personal gain, but for the good of all the people. This is how my people lived for thousands of years, this is the true Native American way.🌎💕🌎
-

image.alt_text: Photo by ᴅᴀɴᴛᴇ ʙɪꜱꜱ-ɢʀᴀʏꜱᴏɴ in Connecticut. May be an image of 1 person.
image.caption:
“Resilience: Honoring Those Lost, Those Murdered, and Those Who Still Search” Poetry and Discussion with Osage Artist Dante Biss-Grayson

@iaismuseum 
@fivepointsartsct 
@skyeaglecollection 

The installation explores the root causes of the MMIW epidemic. Through spreading awareness the artist promotes actionable change. According to the Urban Health Institute, 5,712 cases of MMIW were reported in 2016, of these, only 116 were logged into the Department of Justice Database. 

Dante Biss-Grayson, in this ongoing installation honors those lost, those missing, and those murdered. The work is a live creation which will include, open discussions, poetry creation, art creation, new media, and virtual activism via social media platforms. By creating art, and externalizing the emotions felt, the artist intends to bring greater awareness to this issue, and inspire action.
Space is limited for the in-person event; pre-registration is recommended.Questions? Please call (860) 868-0518 or email events@iaismuseum.org. This is a FREE event, but donations are appreciated.

Donations will go towards a scholarship fund for emerging Native artists

image.alt_text: Photo by yavapaicolorado on December 24, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Northwest Tribes (Yakima, Nez Perce, etc.) Plains Tribes (Sioux, Cheyenne, Pawnee, etc.) Eastern Forest EFsTribes Tribes (Iroquois, Delaware, Miami, etc.) California (Pima,Maricopa) (Pima, Maricopa) Tribes ) Tribes (Shoshone, Paiute) Southeast Tribes (Cherokee, (,,eek) Chickasaw, Navajo Pueblo Apache'.
image.caption:
The Various Phenotypes of Indigenous Americans. The result of American Indian, composite images from historical photos. You can see all the variety of appearances that there are among all the different regions of the US. One thing I noticed is that while each region has its own typical look, there are individuals who look somewhat out of place. For example, you could find a Sioux who looks more typical for Apache. That is why I believe it does not make sense to divide the tribes up into specific phenotypes like 'Silvid' or 'Pacifid' as the old anthropologists did.
-

May be an image of tree and text that says 'Kuwahs Kuwahs*nahawi nahawi Yotuni I am the granddaughter of residential school survivors. am a colonized, marginalized, traumatized Indigenous youth of yesterday, who grew up in the city of London, ON, and Toronto, ON. and today...'.
image.caption:
Believe in yourself and don’t give up.  You are here for a reason.  Your ancestors fought hard for you to be here.  They are here.  You are here.  They are resilient and you are resilient. 

I am the granddaughter of residential school survivors.  I am a colonized, marginalized, traumatized Indigenous youth of yesterday, who grew up in the city of London, ON, and Toronto, ON. and today…

I am an Indigenous Woman Innovator, Community Activist, Economic Developer & Advocate, Business Coach and Mentor for Indigenous Youth & Women. I am still here.  I am Resilient. 

I am the Founder of two social enterprises. Wearing many hats, I am an innovative Anti-Racist Educator, Consultant, Strategic Planner, Program Developer, Facilitator & Trainer.  We are still here.  We are resilient.

image.alt_text: Photo by Soko Fotohaus in Budapest, Hungary with @luxxreadytowear, and @dallas_arcandjr. May be a closeup of one or more people and beard.
image.caption:
Hair has very sacred and special meaning in various cultures around the world throughout human history. 

For Indigenous and Native American Peoples, long hair is encouraged for both males and females.  Hair is their connection to the creator, ancestors and Land or Mother Earth. Others believe long hair is a physical manifestation of growth in spirit, grants extra sensory perception and connection to all things. 

Generally, the only time they cut their hair is when they grieve the loss of loved ones.  The cut represents time spent with the loved ones which is over and new growth is the life after.  Hair is also cut during life changing experiences or traumatic events and to start over on a brand new journey in life.  Braided hair is union with the creator.  Long free flowing hair is freedom of life. Cut hair is ceremonially sent down the rivers, buried or burned with sage or sweetgrass and not simply thrown away. 

When Indigenous and Native American children were forcefully taken away from their families and placed in residential schools and Indian boarding schools in the attempt to assimilate them to the European Settlers’ cultures, aside from not allowing to speak their languages, wear their traditional clothes, practice their religions or perform traditional dances, the children’s long hair were cut thereby taking away their cultures, traditions, hopes, dreams, identities, individualities, pride, and sense of belonging in their communities.  This was known as kill the Indian in the child or take the Indian out of the child campaign.

Current dress code for boys and men prohibits long hair in schools, athletics, social groups and places of employment.  Other people also ridicule or bully boys and men with long hair / braided hair as being less than manly.

Indigenous and Native American Peoples are now reclaiming their cultures and traditions by wearing their hair long again, free flowing and or in braids. 
.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by fremontchefnative on January 01, 2022. May be art.
image.caption:
Just because someone stumbles and loses their way, does not mean they will always be lost. We are like the wind and water, where we are gravitated by unseen forces to flow in one direction, one destination. There will be many times in our flowingness that we will be diverted from our true destination, but our heart will always correct this and help us to resume our course. We can easily be influenced by outside forces that for a time we feel is giving us what we need, but truly if it is diverting us from our flowingness and destination than it probably is not good for us. We are only energy like the elements and when you are hollow bones than you are more able to stay on that course because you easily feel the flow of no resistance to oneself. When you have finally learned the most important lessons that are unique to your spirit, and your energy finally flows in least resistance, than you will become a permanent spirit that no longer comes to Mother Earth. You will become a spirit guide for the one who is greater, and you will give your guidance and enlightenment to the lower evolved here on Mother Earth.🌎⭐💕

image.alt_text: Photo by Tree of Life Mystery School on November 15, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'IN 2016, 5712 NATIVE WOMEN WERE REPORTED MURDERED OR MISSING, NOW WE HAVE LOST COUNT.'.
image.caption:
This month is Indigenous Peoples Heritage Month, and we want to help raise awareness and support about an issue that is very important to us.  There is a tragic epidemic that is deeply impacting the Native communities, their women are being abducted and murdered at an alarming rate that is ten times higher than the national average. During this month we will be sharing weekly posts dedicated to informing you about this issue. Please help us spread the word about this ongoing problem by sharing them with your following Young women on reservations are at high risk because these predators know they will not have to face the law, due to jurisdictional issues. Young women and girls in Native communities have to be on much higher alert than almost anyone else.

Today we would like to highlight MMIW USA, a non-profit organization that tracks the murdered and indigenous women that have been trafficked. In 2016 ALONE, 5712 Native women were reported murdered or missing, and now they have lost count. Please take a look and get involved. Keep an eye out for these women, and spread awareness that this is happening. We will continue to fight for these women to feel safe for as long as it takes!
https://mmiwusa.org/

Here are some IG accounts to follow to learn more:
@mmiw_usa @mmiwhoismissing @mmiw_media @mmiwmatter @mmiw.awareness @csvanw

image.alt_text: Photo by Vanessa Lillie (she / her) in Providence, Rhode Island. May be a closeup of one or more people, eyeglasses and text that says 'VANESSA'.
image.caption:
Hello there! I wanted to just share a couple fun updates - it’s been a minute!

💙 I co-wrote an @audible original with @kimberlysbelle @laynefargo & @cateholahan we’re counting down the days until it’s out in April - it’s called Young Rich Widows - it’s set in the 80s, we each have a POV character & it was the most fun ever to write! We just heard our narrators (Omggggg!) & the cover is 🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥 - lots more on that SOON!

💙 My third thriller, Blood Sisters, is still being edited but I’m getting sooo close! This story (like my other two) has personal ties & meaning (my Cherokee heritage, Oklahoma hometown, themes around belonging, & #mmiwg advocacy). Though I’ve been working on this story almost two years, it’s still early in it’s journey but I’m trusting it will all come together when the time is right.

💙 IG Lives + giveaways continue! I’m getting the 2022 guests organized & it’s going to be another fun year of Twas the Night Before Book Launch! I’ve had 30+ guests already & so excited to keep this party going! Thank YOU for joining me!

💙 Book sale! Ya’ll my debut thriller Little Voices is on sale for 99! It’s the dark & twisted book of my new mom heart (with 3,800+ reviews on Amazon)! Link in stories!

video.caption:
❣️Tag Your Favs In The Comments❣️NOVEMBER IS NATIVE AMERICAN MONTH

Take the time to listen to Native people & their experiences.

Value those who want to share and try not to take offense to those who don't want to share...some of us process historical trauma differently.

List curated by @femislay 

#nativeheritagemonth #indigenousintentions #mmiwg #indigenouspeoplesday

Today was cold, but incredibly moving 🙌 Tiawenhk inenh to everyone today for your incredible energy and creativity to pay tribute and raise awareness for our Stolen Sisters. Today we toughed the cold to film a portion of my grant project to raise awareness for the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and 2 Spirited Peoples. MMIW are Murdered at a higher rate than any other ethnicity, despite the fact that we only make up 4% of the population. Our Stolen Sisters are Unforgotten ✊

Educating yourself is one of the best ways to celebrate Native American Heritage Month! Here are some book recommendations to help you do just that: 
1. 21 Things You May Not Know About the Indian Act
2. Fire Keeper’s Daughter
3. Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee
4. Seven Fallen Feathers
5. How Alcohol is Killing My People (and Yours)
